head.headtext: Character evidence—Criminal cases—Past sexual behavior of victim

para.paratext: Through O.C.G.A. § 24-4-412, the “Rape Shield Statute,” Georgia law specifically limits the admission of character evidence relating to the sexual history of a victim of sexual assault. The statute protects victims of such offenses from being re-victimized by irrelevant character attacks at trial and “assists the truth-seeking process by preventing the jury from becoming inflamed or impassioned and deciding the case on irrelevant and prejudicial evidence.”[1] This statute disallows evidence of a complainant's past sexual behavior in a rape prosecution, including, but not limited to the complainant's “marital history, mode of dress, general reputation for promiscuity, non-chastity, or sexual mores contrary to the community standards.”[2]
Evidence not related to the victim's “sexual behavior” is not prohibited by the statute and may be admitted.[3]
The time of night a victim usually comes home and the victim's reputation for “partying” have also been held inadmissible under the statute.[4]

Courts have interpreted the statute to cover most types of sexually related lawsuits including child molestation,[5] sexual battery,[6] rape, aggravated sodomy, aggravated child molestation, aggravated sexual battery, kidnapping with bodily injury, where the victim was raped;[7] aggravated assault with the intent to rape;[8] incest;[9] and statutory rape.[10]
Curiously, in 2011, the Georgia Court of Appeals held that the rape shield statute did not apply in a prosecution of child molestation and sexual battery involving an 11-year-old victim.[11]

When applicable, the rule precludes the admission of evidence relating to the past sexual behavior of the victim except in certain limited circumstances. Evidence relating to the past sexual behavior of the victim is only admissible (1) to show that someone other than the defendant caused the injuries to the victim, (2) to show that the defendant could have reasonably believed that the witness consented to the conduct, (3) when offered by the prosecution regarding specific sexual behavior of a victim or a complaining witness with respect to the defendant or another person, or (4) when exclusion of the evidence would violate the defendant's constitutional rights.[12]

Where consent of the victim is an issue, O.C.G.A. § 24-4-412(b) requires that the court find that (1) the past sexual behavior in question directly involved the accused and (2) the evidence supports an inference that the accused could have reasonably believed that the complaining witness consented before admitting the evidence.

Defense seeking to introduce evidence of the victim's past sexual history must notify the court of its intention at which time the trial court will conduct an in camera hearing to examine the offer of proof. If the court finds that the evidence “is so highly material that it will substantially support a conclusion that the accused reasonably believed that the complaining witness consented to the conduct complained of and that justice mandates the admission of such evidence,” the court will enter an order specifying “what evidence may be introduced by the defense at the trial of the case and in what manner the evidence may be introduced.”[13]

The Court of Appeals again declined to allow evidence of sexual misconduct of the victim where a grandfather was charged with child molestation and he sought to introduce evidence of sexual contact between the victim and a third party, where the victim had denied having any sexual contact with the third party and later admitted to having a hickey on her neck from him. The court reasoned this failed the second prong test because the allegations were not false allegations by the victim, but rather, they were denials that the sexual contact had occurred at all.[14]

In Villafranco v. State,[15] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the statute does not exclude impeachment evidence which contradicts a rape victim's direct testimony. Thus, because the victim volunteered that she was wearing the underwear that the state introduced into evidence, the court found testimony by the victim's coworker that the victim had said that she did not wear underwear to be admissible as circumstantial evidence to impeach the victim's testimony. Villafranco also held admissible the following statement made by the victim and overheard by an independent witness shortly before the alleged rape: “I want to go to the party to get me some nookey [sic].” The court reasoned that this testimony was not evidence of past sexual behavior and was admissible as evidence of existing motive and state of mind.[16]

In Smith v. State,[17] a decision later overruled, the Georgia Supreme Court held admissible certain testimony that the alleged rape victim had lied about sexual misconduct by men other than the defendant. The court reasoned that evidence of prior false accusations by the victim did not involve the victim's past sexual conduct, but rather involved the victim's propensity for making false statements regarding sexual conduct and was therefore not barred by the rape shield statute, and that both the Sixth Amendment right to confrontation and the Fourteenth Amendment's due process clause guaranteeing a defendant a meaningful opportunity to present a defense demanded a bright line rule for admissibility of evidence of prior false allegations.[18] In 2019, however, the Court overruled this decision and its progeny in State v. Burns.[19] The Court held that Smith was wrongly decided “based on a misunderstanding of federal Constitutional Law,” and that instead, the courts should apply the familiar and usual rules of evidence, mainly O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403, to determine whether the prior false allegation of a complaining witness in a sexual offense prosecution should be excluded, rather than the bright-line rule of admissibility espoused in Smith. The Court bolstered its decision with language from Nevada v. Jackson,[20] where the U.S. Supreme Court stated it had never held that the Confrontation Clause “entitles a criminal defendant to introduce extrinsic evidence for impeachment purposes.” The Georgia Supreme Court's analysis of the evidence under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403 weighed the credibility of the witness and the fact that the witness made a prior false allegation, looked at the possibility of the jury deciding the case on an improper motive, and looked at confusion issues. In this case, the Court concluded that O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403 did not pose a bar to the jury's learning about the false statement. Thus, trial courts must now conduct the analysis under Rule 403 for the admissibility of evidence of previous false accusations of sexual misconduct.

In Reece v. State,[21] the Georgia Court of Appeals held admissible evidence from which the jury might have speculated that a 12-year-old complainant in a rape case was sexually active: the witness physician testified that the complainant had developed a vaginal infection after the time of the alleged rape and that the complainant maintained that she had not had sexual intercourse with anyone else. In response to this testimony, the defendant sought to introduce his wife's medical records, which showed his wife did not have any type of vaginal infection. The defendant offered the records as circumstantial evidence that he had not had sexual intercourse with the complainant because he would have contracted the same type of infection as the complainant, if he had intercourse with her, and he also would have transmitted it to his wife. In reversing the conviction, the court held that the defendant should have been allowed to introduce the proffered records under the theory advanced and in response to the prejudicial testimony elicited by the State.

Citing Villafranco, supra, the court reversed a rape conviction in White v. State[22] because the defendant had not been allowed to introduce evidence that the victim had “several common vaginal infections” when examined by a doctor after the alleged rape. The court held that this was not evidence of the victim's past sexual behavior, which violated the rape shield statute, but was relevant to impeach the victim's statement that she had contracted a vaginal infection from the defendant at the time of the rape and to the defendant's claim that he did not penetrate the victim because of her physical condition.

Similarly, in Warner v. State,[23] the court found a victim's testimony that she had not had sex for five months prior to the rape relevant to exclude the possibility that someone other than the defendant had infected her with the herpes virus.

Also, in Lemacks v. State,[24] the court found that the rape shield statute did not bar evidence of a victim's prior molestations to show that someone other than the defendant caused the injuries. Citing Raines v. State,[25] the court held that the rape shield law does not exclude evidence of prior molestation since a forcible sexual offense is not evidence of “past sexual behavior of the complaining witness.”

“Past sexual behavior” may include any behavior occurring prior to trial and is not limited simply to that behavior occurring before the offense at issue. In Murrell v. Ricks,[26] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the admission of evidence proving a 14-year-old child molestation victim tested positive for a sexually transmitted disease one year after the alleged offense was inadmissible under the rape shield statute because, while it could not be determined when the victim had contracted the disease, “the law makes no distinction between the victim's behavior before or after the crime.”

Likewise in Birdsong v. State,[27] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that defense counsel's question as to how often the victim had engaged in sexual intercourse after the alleged rape was barred by the rape shield statute despite the defendant's contention that the question was intended to impeach victim's claim to have been traumatized by the alleged rape. The court stated that, unless the questioned sexual behavior directly involved the participation of the defendant and supported an inference that he could have reasonably believed that his wife consented to the sexual intercourse for which he was being prosecuted, the question was improper.

Evidence of a victim's prior miscarriage may also be excluded under the rape shield statute.[28] Additionally, evidence of a child's exposure to sexually explicit material is clearly inadmissible under the rape shield statute.[29]

Fed. R. Evid. 412 specifically excludes evidence of a victim's past sexual behavior in prosecutions for sexual assault. However, Rule 412 also explicitly applies in civil cases involving alleged sexual misconduct. While Georgia courts have recognized the public policy of protecting the privacy of a sexual assault victim,[30] the Georgia rule does not address noncriminal proceedings. Rule 412 expressly recognizes three circumstances where such evidence may be admitted at trial. Like the Georgia rule, in a criminal case, the federal rule admits evidence that would demonstrate an alternative explanation for the physical evidence.[31] For example, the defendant could offer the testimony of a witness that he had sexual relations with the victim around the time of the alleged rape, thus explaining the presence of physical evidence.[32] Also like the Georgia rule, the defendant may offer evidence that the defendant and the victim had previously had sexual relations, demonstrating a defense of consent.[33] The federal practice also provides for the admission of such evidence as required by the United States Constitution.[34] “This exception is intended to cover those infrequent instances where, because of an unusual chain of circumstances, the general rule of inadmissibility, if followed, would result in denying the defendant a constitutional right.”[35]

In a civil case, the federal rule admits the prior sexual history of the victim if that evidence would be otherwise admissible under the rules, and the probative value substantially outweighs the harm to the victim and unfair prejudice to any party.[36] Reputation evidence about the victim's sexual history is admissible only if the victim has placed the reputation in controversy.[37]
See Mooney v. State, 266 Ga. App. 587, 592–593, 597 S.E.2d 589 (2004) (overruled on other grounds by, White v. State, 305 Ga. 111, 823 S.E.2d 794 (2019)).

Richardson v. State, 276 Ga. 639, 581 S.E.2d 528 (2003) (statute did not prohibit questioning of victim about her desire to rekindle romantic relationship with former boyfriend as long as cross-examination did not implicate victim's sexual behavior).
Lockhart v. State, 172 Ga. App. 170, 322 S.E.2d 503 (1984).
Pullen v. State, 208 Ga. App. 581, 431 S.E.2d 696 (1993).
Bates v. State, 216 Ga. App. 597, 454 S.E.2d 811 (1995).
Singleton v. State, 157 Ga. App. 192, 276 S.E.2d 685 (1981).
Blount v. State, 172 Ga. App. 120, 322 S.E.2d 323, 21 Ed. Law Rep. 386 (1984).
Estes v. State, 165 Ga. App. 453, 301 S.E.2d 504 (1983) (overruled on other grounds by, Brown v. State, 274 Ga. 31, 549 S.E.2d 107 (2001)).
Johnson v. State, 146 Ga. App. 277, 246 S.E.2d 363 (1978).

The consent portion of the rape shield statute is inapplicable in statutory rape cases since consent is irrelevant. Johnson v. State, 146 Ga. App. 277, 246 S.E.2d 363 (1978). See also Berry v. State, 210 Ga. App. 789, 437 S.E.2d 630 (1993) (rape shield law prohibited introduction of evidence that victim of alleged statutory rape had sexual intercourse with persons other than defendant).
Robinson v. State, 308 Ga. App. 562, 708 S.E.2d 303 (2011).

O.C.G.A. § 24-4-412(b). The statute was amended effective April 18, 2019, to allow admissibility of evidence of past conduct offered by the prosecution. Before the change in statute, such evidence was held inadmissible if offered by the state for a reason other than consent. See White v. State, 305 Ga. 111, 823 S.E.2d 794 (2019).
Frye v. State, 344 Ga. App. 704, 811 S.E.2d 460 (2018).
Villafranco v. State, 252 Ga. 188, 313 S.E.2d 469 (1984).
Villafranco v. State, 252 Ga. 188, 313 S.E.2d 469 (1984).

See also Shelton v. State, 196 Ga. App. 163, 395 S.E.2d 618 (1990), evidence that a victim had previously made false accusations of sexual misconduct against others would be relevant and therefore admissible.
State v. Burns, 829 S.E.2d 367 (Ga. 2019).
Reece v. State, 192 Ga. App. 14, 383 S.E.2d 572 (1989).
White v. State, 201 Ga. App. 53, 410 S.E.2d 441 (1991).
Warner v. State, 277 Ga. App. 421, 626 S.E.2d 620 (2006) (overruled on other grounds by, White v. State, 305 Ga. 111, 823 S.E.2d 794 (2019)).
Lemacks v. State, 207 Ga. App. 160, 427 S.E.2d 536 (1993).
Birdsong v. State, 298 Ga. App. 322, 680 S.E.2d 159 (2009).
Smith v. State, 294 Ga. App. 692, 670 S.E.2d 191 (2008).
Walker v. State, 308 Ga. App. 176, 707 S.E.2d 122 (2011).

See also Montgomery v. State, 277 Ga. App. 142, 142–44, 625 S.E.2d 529 (2006) (child's potential exposure to brother's collection of pornography held irrelevant to alleged molestation); Callahan v. State, 256 Ga. App. 482, 485–86, 568 S.E.2d 780 (2002) (child's exposure to a household with open sexual activity and observation of such held irrelevant); Cantrell v. State, 225 Ga. App. 680, 680–81, 484 S.E.2d 751 (1997) (child's exposure to mother's sexual activity and father's pornographic magazines held irrelevant to claims of molestation).
Macon Telegraph Pub. Co. v. Tatum, 208 Ga. App. 111, 430 S.E.2d 18 (1993), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 263 Ga. 678, 436 S.E.2d 655 (1993).
Fed. R. Evid. 412(b)(1).
See U.S. v. Powers, 59 F.3d 1460, 42 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 645 (4th Cir. 1995).
Fed. R. Evid. 412(b)(1); see, e.g., U.S. v. Boyles, 57 F.3d 535, 42 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 550 (7th Cir. 1995).
Fed. R. Evid. 412(b)(1).
See, e.g., U.S. v. Bear Stops, 997 F.2d 451, 38 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 352 (8th Cir. 1993).
Fed. R. Evid. 412, Advisory Committee Notes.
Fed. R. Evid. 412(b)(2).
See also Judd v. Rodman, 105 F.3d 1339, 46 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 535 (11th Cir. 1997).
Fed. R. Evid. 412(b)(2).
